data.text: Contents
Introduction

This policy is part of the Trust's overall recruitment process and details the Trust's arrangements for work health assessment. It should be read in conjunction with the Recruitment Policy and Staff Immunisation and Health Screening Policy.

Employers have a duty of care to their employees to ensure that they and their workplaces are safe and healthy in line with health and safety obligations and equality law. Work health assessments have an important role in helping employer's identity and consider early on, any health condition or disability that may require:
Adjustments being made to the workplace to enable the individual to safely carry out the duties they have been engaged to carry out.

Restrictions being placed on their duties, for example exposure prone procedures (EPPs) for workers who have a blood borne virus which may have impact on patient's care. All staff undertaking exposure prone procedures must undertake additional health clearance before doing so.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Outline the importance of a work health assessment;
Provide clarity when and who needs to have work health assessment.
Definitions

table_items.text: A work health assessment refers to a variety of processes undertaken by employers to health screen staff to assess whether they are capable and fit to undertake a particular role. Its primary purpose is to help prevent work-related illnesses, injuries and the spread of disease or infection. The extent of any health assessment will be dependent on the requirements and risks associated with any given role which impact on the health and wellbeing of either the individual carrying out that role and /or any patients they may have contact with.

Those procedures where the workers gloved hand may be in contact with sharp instruments, needle tips and sharp tissues (spicules of bone or teeth) inside a patient's body cavity, wound or confined anatomical space where the hands or fingertips may not be completely visible at all times.
Stand-alone Occupational Health record IT system. Separate from
the personnel file and only accessed by Occupational Health
NHS Employers streamlining programme aims to help with effective HR processes for all NHS to NHS staff transfers, minimising the time taken to employ staff.

data.text: Roles and responsibilities within the Trust

The Trust Board is responsible for ensuring the policy is applied throughout the Trust through its Chief Executive, Directors, Managers and Employees. Responsibilities may be delegated to the Workforce Sub-Committee
The Chief Executive has overall responsibility for ensuring the Trust has management systems in place to enable the effective and safe implementation of this policy.
The Chief People and Organisational Development Officer is the named officer responsible for ensuring that the content of this policy is applied fairly and consistently across the Trust.
Department Managers are responsible for ensuring:
That all staff are aware of the contents of this policy
That appropriate risk assessments are in place for tasks involving exposure to infectious diseases.

That all staff have received the appropriate health clearance by Occupational Health before commencing work. It is the recruiting manager's responsibility to decide whether to employ the applicant in light of reports from occupational health and other relevant information.
That temporary staff have been cleared to the same standard which applies to Trust employees
That the HR recruitment team are advised of all posts that will require staff to be cleared for exposure prone procedures
That no healthcare worker is allowed to undertake exposure prone procedures until health clearance has been issued by Occupational Health
All Employees are responsible for ensuring:
To complete the work health assessment as part of the recruitment process and when changing roles within the Trust
That they inform their line manager if they have not been vaccinated against or are not immune to any of the vaccine preventable diseases for which they would routinely have been offered vaccination
That they report any signs or symptoms of TB or other potentially infectious disease to Occupational Health both at pre-employment and during employment.

That they are aware of their duty of care to patients, and any member of staff who may have been exposed to a serious communicable disease, in whatever circumstances, must seek and follow confidential professional advice (e.g. from Occupational health) about whether to undergo testing
Human Resources Department are responsible for ensuring:

That no staff member commences employment until an appropriate health clearance certificate has been issued by Occupational Health, including confirmation of clearance to undertake Exposure Prone Procedures, (EEP). Students will have clearance from their own University Occupational Health Departments'.
That all new starters and those changing jobs within the Trust, complete a pre- employment questionnaire which is forwarded to Occupational Health for the work health assessment.
The Occupational Health and Wellbeing Service (OH) is responsible for:
Undertaking health work assessments on employment or following role change within the Trust in line with current employment policies.
Providing clearance on new employees if fit to commence work, or advice regarding work adjustments following health work assessment.
Performing appropriate screening if individuals are unable to produce adequate evidence of immunity / non-infectivity.
Issuing health clearance for EPP roles only when appropriate screening results have been obtained.
Notifying the recruitment manager or line manager when staff fail to attend OH appointments for a work health assessment.
Notifying the recruitment manager or line manager when an individual declines vaccination with a report stating that Occupational Health clearance cannot be provided.
Maintaining accurate and contemporaneous records of staff vaccinations and work health assessments.

Will assess the immunity of Trust staff in line with the recommendations outlined in "The Green Book" to determine which vaccinations or serology are required for specific job role or responsibilities.

Volunteers. All pre-employment checks are carried out in accordance with the NHS Employment Check Standards, which are mandatory for all applicants for NHS positions in on-going NHS employment, including volunteers. Those directly recruited by the Trust will have a work health assessment and should be made aware of the Trust immunisation and health screening policy. Immunisation and screening will be undertaken commensurate with their role.

Agency staff / students /honorary contracts / work placements / contractors must comply with the work health assessment policy as well as vaccination and screening standards. Those in the Trust responsible for agency contracts will ensure that the organisations they are contracting with comply with the policy standards.
Work health assessment process
Key requirements

The Trust will consider requirements of the Equality Act Section  (2010)¹ which describes the specific circumstances under which employers can legally ask questions about an applicant's health or disability prior to making an offer of appointment. This applies regardless as to whether the offer is conditional or unconditional.

The Trust will also ensure that people with disabilities are not disadvantaged during the recruitment process and are treated fairly when considering working arrangements and the working environment. As far as practical, any reasonable adjustments will be considered.
Who to check and when
Health assessment is carried out for all individuals applying for posts within the Trust, including permanent staff, temporary workers, students, trainees and volunteers. This includes when:
When an individual who is not currently employed by the Trust applies for a role
An existing member of staff is returning to work following a serious injury or illness and there is a need to assess whether they can safely return to their normal duties.
An existing member of staff moves to a different job within the Trust
Assessments should take place after an offer of appointment but prior to the commencement of their employment.

It is unlawful for applicants to be asked to complete a pre-employment health questionnaire or to ask questions as part of their application or interview process, for any reason other than the exceptional circumstances outlined within the Equality Act (2010)
Any offer of employment is conditional pending the completion of pre-appointment checks, including a relevant health assessment.
Health assessments are carried out by the Occupational Health Department in accordance with equal opportunities legislation and good occupational health practice.
Agency / external contractor requirements
Workers supplied by an agency or other external contractor under a framework agreement should have the work health assessment undertaken by an accredited occupational health provider.
The Trust will ensure that the agencies are clear about what levels of clearances (including vaccination requirements) are required for different positions.
Written confirmation is obtained to confirm that appropriate assessment has been carried out; the worker is fit to start work and, if there is any reasonable adjustments that need to be considered.

The Trust will only carry out a further work health assessment on agency workers if there has been a significant change to the nature of work and/or working environment, or if there is a change in to the workers' health condition.
Streamlining
There may be an option to reduce duplication of immunisation/vaccination requirements by reviewing the Electronic Staff Record (ESR) if appropriate and with consent from the employee.
The assessment process
The offer letter will advise the applicant to complete a pre-employment health questionnaire via Cohort. The health questionnaire is processed by Occupational Health. (See appendix 1)
The questionnaire is assessed within Occupational Health by the Occupational Health Advisor (OHA) or Immunisation Nurse (depending upon complexity) who will make one of the following decisions:
Whether the individual is fit for the role and can start work
Or:
Further information or clarification is required before a decision on fitness can be made by:
A work health assessment by telephone consultation with either the Occupational Health Advisor or Occupational Health Physician to gain further information on a declared health condition
Attendance is required for immunisation or serology for EPP before clearance can be determined
If individual is deemed fit for the role and can start work with reasonable adjustments made – then this will include recommendations outlining what adjustments need to be considered.
Any immunisation and/or EPP clearance (where applicable to the role) will be stated on the fitness for work document that is sent to recruitment
Information regarding any particular condition will be revealed to management only if the applicant provides consent.
Risk assessment

Managers are required to undertake the necessary assessments to effectively manage any risks to the health and safety of employees, patients and others on Trust premises, under the Health and Safety at Work Act (1974) and The Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulation (1999)². Individual risk assessments may be required on commencement of a new role or change in health circumstances.
Information regarding any particular condition will be revealed to management only if the applicant provides consent.
The risk assessment should:
Identify any hazards that exist in the workplace
Address how likely these hazards are to cause harm to workers, patients and others on the premises
Identify any control measures that will need to be put in place.
Advice can be sought from the local Health and Safety manager.
Considering reasonable adjustment
The Equality Act (2010) outlines a series of provisions which place a duty on employers to make reasonable adjustments for job applicants who have a disability.

The aim of making reasonable adjustments is to reduce as far as possible, any significant disadvantages that may be presented to an individual with a disability that would not affect a non-disabled person. This may include reviewing how the employment is structured, removal of physical barriers or providing additional support to the individual, such as:
Making practical adjustments to the premises
Altering the individuals working hours
Allowing absences during working hours for medical treatment
Additional training
Providing special equipment or modifying existing equipment
Changing instructions or reference manuals
Providing additional supervision and support
Access to work scheme

The Access to Work Scheme can provide some financial support with the steps that need to be taken to support an individual within the workplace. Application for the scheme needs to be made by the employee.
Additional considerations
Immunisation: requirements for healthcare workers

The requirements to ensure immunisation against common communicable infections and biological hazards will be dependent upon an individual's role in the Trust, and the risks of exposure the role may pose. Further information regarding immunisation is outlined in the Trusts MSEPO-20258 Staff Immunisation and Health Screening Policy.
Exposure prone procedures

Additional screening may be required for workers involved in EPPs, patient care, patient contact or body fluid sample handling. Further information regarding EPP screening is outlined in the Trusts Staff Immunisation and Health Screening Policy MSEPO-20258.

Individuals carrying out EPPs have a professional duty to ensure that they are tested and assessed for HIV, hepatitis B and hepatitis C. If at any time they should acquire or be at risk of acquiring any of these infections, they must refrain from carrying out work that involves EPP and inform Occupational Health. All testing is carried out with informed consent. Further information is available from the Trusts MSEPO 21047 Health Clearance and Management of Healthcare Workers Living with Blood Borne Viruses Policy.
Additional screening
Additional screening may be carried out in accordance with the Equality Act (2010), dependent upon local needs and risks associated with different roles.
Decision making
Occupational Health will provide a specialist and confidential service to both the prospective employee and the Trust.
The decision to appoint the individual ultimately sits with the recruiting manager and will need to ensure that:
The health clearance process has been completed and all relevant information has been considered
A risk assessment has been carried out to identify any reasonable adjustments that may need to be considered for the post

Advice has been sought from all the relevant departments such as HR, occupational health and health and safety in relation to ensuring all reasonable adjustments have been fully considered and, where appropriate can be put in place
If the recruiting manager chooses to appoint an individual, despite concerns being expressed by the occupational health service, the manager will need to record the justification for the decision.
Withdrawal of appointment
Refusal of employment on health grounds will only occur if:
Expert occupational medical advice has been sought
The applicant has had the opportunity to discuss issues raised with an occupational health professional or
The employing manager has given full consideration of the facts, with advice from HR.
Retaining and transferring health records

Health assessment information does not form part of a worker's personnel record for reasons of confidentiality and is retained separately on Cohort in line with data protection requirements (GDPR 2018 and Data Protection Act 2018). Reports and summaries may be held on an individual's personnel record when the individual has given consent.
Training requirements

Whilst there is no specific training identified in relation to this policy, the Trust recognises the importance of appropriate training for staff. Reference to this policy is made in managers training. Line managers will be required to ensure their respective staffs are made aware of this policy when this is cascaded through the usual dissemination routes.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the HR Policy Woking Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the HR Policy Woking Group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.

Employment Health Assessment
Welcome to our Trust

We are writing to introduce the Occupational Health Service. The Trust and Occupational Health and Wellbeing service take the health and wellbeing of all staff very seriously. Our role in Occupational Health is both to advise you how to remain well at work; and to advise the Trust about any adaptations that could be made at work to help you to do your job.

This health at work questionnaire gives us information which helps us to identify any health condition which could pose a risk to you, your colleagues, patients or members of the public or that could affect your ability to undertake the duties of the post you have been offered.

The health information you provide will remain confidential to the Occupational Health Service. This means that the information you put on the form will not be disclosed to anyone else without your explicit consent, although some of the information may be used internally as part of the routine auditing of the Occupational Health Service.
What will we do with my form?
If you have provided all the relevant information, we will automatically inform recruitment of the ‘clearance' decision

Section 5 Exposure Prone Procedure (EPP) Workers and Renal Dialysis Workers Only
Definition: EPPs are those procedures where the worker's gloved hands may be in full contact with sharp instruments,
needle tips or sharp tissue (e.g. spicules of bone or teeth) inside a patient's open body cavity, wound or confined
anatomical space where the hands or fingertips may not be completely visible at all times.
EPP staff include but are not limited to: All surgeons (including FY1 and FY2 doctors with a rotation into one of the EPP
areas), dental staff, theatre staff, midwives, A&E doctors and nurses.
EPP staff must provide identified validated documentary evidence of their Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C and HIV status; health
clearance for EPP work cannot be given until this evidence is received by the Occupational Health Department, health
clearance may be delayed until these results are processed. We do not accept GP reports, or any hand written
documentation of these tests. If you do not have this information available you will need to attend Occupational Health for
blood tests before you can be health cleared to start work. You will be contacted if a blood test is required. If an
appointment is made for blood tests, please bring with you photographic identification e.g.: passport, driving licence, Trust

Section 8 Food Handlers - Only to complete this section
Definition: Where it is used, the term ‘food handler' mainly refers to people who directly touch open food as part of
their work. They can be employed or agency staff.
However, it also includes anyone who may touch food contact surfaces or other surfaces in rooms where open food
is handled. This is because they can also contaminate food by spreading bacteria for example to surfaces that food
will come into contact with, e.g. work tops and food packaging before it is used. They can also contaminate other
surfaces such as door handles which can then contaminate the hands of people who handle food directly for
The term can therefore apply to managers, cleaners, maintenance contractors and inspectors for example. It is the
effect of their presence that is important, not the reason for them being there.
